title: Employer Nomination Scheme visa (subclasses 121 and 856)
raw_text: ===== main placeholder ========================================== ​This visa is closed to new applications. Employer Nomination Scheme visa (subclasses 121 and 856) Page Content ​​The Employer Nomination visa (subclasses 121 and 856) closed to new applications on 1 July 2012. You can add your partner or a dependent child to your application if it has not yet been decided. The Employer Nomination Scheme (ENS) allowed Australian employers to sponsor employees who are foreign nationals for a permanent visa to work in Australia. The Employer Nomination visa (subclasses 121 and 856) visa is for applicants who were in Australia and lodged a visa application on or before 30 June 2012. This visa allows you and your family to live and work in Australia on a permanent basis. About this visa Details Cost Details Employer Nomination Scheme (Subclass 121): Additional applicant charge 18 and over — AUD1,050 Additional applicant charge under 18 — AUD525 Employer Nomination Scheme (Subclass 856): Additional applicant charge 18 and over — AUD1,555 Additional applicant charge under 18 — AUD775 Employer Nomination Scheme - Extension (Subclass 856): Additional applicant charge 18 and over — AUD140 Additional applicant charge under 18 — AUD70 Visa holders Details This information is for people who have been granted an Employer Nomination visa (subclass 121). It explains your rights and obligations. You can use Visa Entitlement Verification Online (VEVO) for free to check your visa details and entitlements. What this visa lets you do Details This is a permanent visa. It allows you and your family to: stay in Australia indefinitely work and study in Australia enrol in Medicare scheme for health-related care and expenses take out private health insurance access certain social security payments be able to get Australian citizenship (if you are eligible) sponsor eligible members of your family unit for permanent residence travel to and from Australia for five years from the date the visa is granted (after that time you will need a resident return visa or another visa to return to Australia). Your obligations Details You and your family must comply with all visa conditions and Australian laws. Employer obligations Details The employer must comply with all relevant Australian standards and workplace legislation for wages and working conditions Tell us if things change Details Things you need to let us know about when you have this visa include: changes to your phone number, email, address or passport changes to your relationship status the birth of a child. See how to let us know if there is a change in your situation If you do not provide us with the details of any new passport issued to you, you could experience significant delays at the airport and may be denied permission to board your plane.

​This visa is closed to new applications.

# Employer Nomination Scheme visa (subclasses 121 and 856)

Employer Nomination Scheme visa (subclasses 121 and 856)
Page Content

​​The Employer Nomination visa (subclasses 121 and 856) closed to new applications on 1 July 2012. You can add your partner or a dependent child to your application if it has not yet been decided.

​​The Employer Nomination visa (subclasses 121 and 856) closed to new applications on 1 July 2012. You can add your partner or a dependent child to your application if it has not yet been decided.

The Employer Nomination Scheme (ENS) allowed Australian employers to sponsor employees who are foreign nationals for a permanent visa to work in Australia. The Employer Nomination visa (subclasses 121 and 856) visa is for applicants who were in Australia and lodged a visa application on or before 30 June 2012.

The Employer Nomination Scheme (ENS) allowed Australian employers to sponsor employees who are foreign nationals for a permanent visa to work in Australia. The Employer Nomination visa (subclasses 121 and 856) visa is for applicants who were in Australia and lodged a visa application on or before 30 June 2012.

This visa allows you and your family to live and work in Australia on a permanent basis.

This visa allows you and your family to live and work in Australia on a permanent basis.

About this visa
Details

## Visa holders

Visa holders
Details

This information is for people who have been granted an Employer Nomination visa (subclass 121). It explains your rights and obligations.

This information is for people who have been granted an Employer Nomination visa (subclass 121). It explains your rights and obligations.

You can useVisa Entitlement Verification Online (VEVO)for free to check your visa details and entitlements.

### What this visa lets you do

What this visa lets you do
Details

This is a permanent visa. It allows you and your family to:

This is a permanent visa. It allows you and your family to:
- stay in Australia indefinitely
stay in Australia indefinitely
- work and study in Australia
work and study in Australia
- enrol inMedicarescheme for health-related care and expenses
enrol in
Medicare
scheme for health-related care and expenses
- take out private health insurance

- access certain social security payments
access certain social security payments
- be able to get Australian citizenship (if you are eligible)
be able to get Australian citizenship (if you are eligible)
- sponsor eligible members of your family unit for permanent residence
sponsor eligible members of your family unit for permanent residence
- travel to and from Australia for five years from the date the visa is granted (after that time you will need a resident return visa or another visa to return to Australia).
travel to and from Australia for five years from the date the visa is granted (after that time you will need a resident return visa or another visa to return to Australia).

### Your obligations

Your obligations
Details

You and your family must comply with all visa conditions and Australian laws.

You and your family must comply with all visa conditions and Australian laws.

### Employer obligations

Employer obligations
Details

The employer must comply with all relevant Australian standards and workplace legislation for wages and working conditions
